image.altText: Sunrise over the Moylan Grain Silos plant in Kellerberrin.

items.synopsis: The tight-knit WA community of Kellerberrin faces a long road to recovery after a father was shot dead by another well-known local resident, sparking a manhunt and police stand-off that forced the town into lockdown.

title.children: Terrorised by one of its own, small town reels from gunman killing local father before turning weapon on himself

image.altText: Payne wearing a red jacket and dark-rimmed glasses looks across frame.

items.synopsis: One of the Liberal Party's most senior women, and the first woman to hold the defence portfolio in Australia, will retire from politics after 26 years in parliament.

title.children: Former minister Marise Payne to quit politics after 26 years

image.altText: Vivienne Mitchell's face and upper body is superimposed over a picture of razors that has a price tag of $43

items.synopsis: Backlash against Coles and Woolworths is swirling on social media as the supermarket giants record large profits amid a cost of living crisis. But one expert says the anger, and calls for a boycott, are unlikely to have a lasting effect.

title.children: How one Australian's 'sheer disbelief' at the rising cost of groceries reached 1.7 million shoppers

image.altText: An image from That '70s Show of a man with curly hair and glasses smiling, next to a photo of a man in a courtroom in a suit

items.synopsis: The star of That '70s Show is facing life in prison for raping two women, in a case which has stirred controversy around the church where he and his victims met.

title.children: How Danny Masterson's rape trial led to allegations against Scientology, and at least 25 years in prison

image.altText: Brahman cattle at Anna Plains Station, July 2022.

items.synopsis: While no formal agreement has been reached, the government says recent discussions have been positive, after the prime minister raised the matter with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo.

title.children: Indonesia poised to resume live cattle imports from Australia

image.altText: Concept graphic of a floating port at Broome. Blue waters, sky in the horizon.

items.synopsis: The director of a major floating jetty project in Western Australia's Kimberley says the construction phase will begin two years after initially planned.

title.children: Construction to begin today on Broome's $200 million floating jetty after years of delays

image.altText: Gerard Rennick sits on the backbench in the Senate looking into the distance

items.synopsis: Coalition senator Gerard Rennick has questioned the basis for claims Australia's Indigenous history dates back more than 60,000 years. What do the experts say?

title.children: What's the evidence for 60,000 years of Indigenous history?

image.altText: A book page with a colourful scene on the left and grey scene on the right.

items.synopsis: Amanda Lieber noticed how distressed a mother was as she dropped her child at a hospital's school. She comforted her, and the experience led her to write about a parent's depression as seen through a child's eyes.

title.children: Amanda wrote a child's book about a parent with depression. A publisher wanted a happy ending

image.altText: A woman sitting in her seat in the House of Representatives

items.synopsis: North Sydney independent MP Kylea Tink says an opposition member yelled at her aggressively in parliament on Wednesday, but Mr Dutton says he has no concerns with the account he's been given.

title.children: Peter Dutton has 'no concerns' about 'aggressive' behaviour of opposition MP

image.altText: A man walks along a road with a jacket over his shoulders and head.

items.synopsis: Greece has been slammed by "extraordinary" downpours from a weather pattern shaped like the final letter of the country's alphabet. Here is why this one was so intense.

title.children: Parts of Greece have recorded an entire year's worth of rain in 18 hours, a month after heatwaves and fire. What's caused it?

image.altText: Queen Elizabeth stands smiling and leaning on a cane next to a lit fireplace.

items.synopsis: The plans for her death were meticulous. Her lavish funeral had a code name. But when the kingdom's second Elizabethan era drew to a close, everyone suddenly seemed to be a little caught off-guard.

title.children: The inside story of the Queen's final hours, and how they foretold the first year of Charles's reign

image.altText: A woman faces side on while wearing a crown and a royal cape.

items.synopsis: The King acknowledged the anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II's death in a short statement shared on social media.

title.children: 'Recall with great affection': Charles marks first anniversary of late queen

image.altText: A protester being taken away by police at the US Open.

items.synopsis: The US Open match between Coco Gauff and Karolína Muchová is delayed for more than 45 minutes following a disruption by environmental activists inside Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title.children: Environmental activist glues his feet to the ground as protest interrupts US Open semifinal

image.altText: A man in a white shirt looks into a food delivery bag

items.synopsis: An analysis of data from China's second largest food delivery service shows that adding a "green nudge" could eliminate more than 3 million tonnes of single-use plastic.

title.children: A simple 'green nudge' could save millions of tonnes of plastic waste each year

image.altText: A South Korean man opens his hands and smiles against a backdrop of a map on a wall showing Fiji and Australia.

items.synopsis: The Grace Road Church, described as a "cult", has been plagued by allegations of detaining hundreds of followers and subjecting some to ritualistic violence.

title.children: Fiji expels doomsday 'cult' members as leader slams 'heavy-handed' police action

image.altText: Military officials look at nuclear sub with red star on its front

items.synopsis: The new vessel — named Hero Kim Kun Ok after a North Korean historical figure — will be assigned to the fleet that patrols the waters between the Korean peninsula and Japan.

title.children: North Korea launches new tactical nuclear attack submarine

image.altText: China 6G

items.synopsis: Chinese state media has pointed to Huawei's new smartphone as evidence the United States' attempts to curtail China's microchip development are failing. So how significant is the tech in the new phone and what does it mean for the "chip wars"?

title.children: Huawei launched a new phone without fanfare last week. But the technology it uses has sparked intense debate

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Scott Morrison

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Scott Morrison has warned that his successor should not be "too keen" to accept an invitation to China, as Anthony Albanese prepares to visit Beijing within months.

title.children: Scott Morrison says Anthony Albanese shouldn't rush to visit Beijing this year

image.altText: Catherine King standing speaking wearing a bright red blazer.

items.synopsis: Could her resurrection of the 2020 strip search incident be one way of seeking to neutralise an issue that has been otherwise debated – to the government's detriment – in terms of limiting competition?

title.children: Catherine King's baffling week leaves more questions than answers on Qatar decision

image.altText: A child sits in a front passenger seat using a phone with the seatbelt over their head

items.synopsis: Transport Minister Mark Bailey said the department is seeking "urgent legal advice on the swift re-issuance of incorrectly suspended licences".

title.children: 'This is our mistake': Transport department issues hundreds of 'incorrect' seatbelt penalties

image.altText: Elderly people sit in chairs and have their feet washed

items.synopsis: Tasmania's largest aged care provider admits underpaying staff $6.9 million over a seven-year period, including one staff member who was owed $220,000.

title.children: Aged care provider underpaid staff $6.9m over seven years

image.altText: Man in red jacket with light on his head

items.synopsis: The operation to rescue the experienced US cave researcher from the depths of southern Türkiye's Taurus Mountains involves teams from Bulgaria, Croatia, Hungary, Italy, Poland and Türkiye.

title.children: Race to save injured explorer 1,000 metres inside cave in Türkiye

image.altText: People cross the road at an intersection in a busy CBD.

items.synopsis: Wall Street finished lower overnight in response to China's ban on iPhones, while corporate regulator ASIC is suing AustralianSuper for allegedly failing to address multiple superannuation accounts belonging to 90,000 customers. Follow live.

title.children: ASIC sues AustralianSuper over $69m 'failure' affecting 90,000 customers, China's iPhone ban hits Wall Street, ASX flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Who is versent telstra wants to buy? - John. Hi John, good question! Let's run through who they are. Versent was founded in 2014 by two former ANZ tech executives, and has grown to employ over 600 people with offices in Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Singapore and Denver. It describes itself as a "leading technology consultancy" that is " pioneering the future of technology " and exists to "architect, build and operate cloud-native applications, data streams, platforms, and services". Translating the marketing speak, it's a technology company that specialises in cloud-based services, with a specific focus on security products. They also provide data insights, product design services, and advisory services. It's also got an impressive number of partners it works with, including Microsoft, Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud, Cloudflare and Crowdstrike, to name a few. Versent also services government organisations and blue-chip companies, and says it works with around 40% of the companies listed on the ASX100 .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Who is Versent, the company Telstra is in talks to buy?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Workers at Chevron's two major liquified natural gas (LNG) projects in WA will begin strike action this afternoon, after mediation talks failed to deliver a resolution. Chevron workers have been arguing for better pay and rostering, and had threatened to start strike action yesterday, before mediation talks were held by the Fair Work Commission. Now, union body Offshore Alliance says those talks have failed to resolve their demands, and strike action will begin from 1pm WST (3pm AEST) — including workers at Gorgon, Australia's second-largest LNG plant, and Wheatstone. The ongoing dispute between Chevron and its workers has been swirling for weeks, and follows the threat of Woodside workers threatening to walk off the job, which sent the price of LNG soaring globally. Australia is the biggest exporter of LNG in the world, and although it mainly supplies customers in Asia, the threat of industrial action has impacted prices in Europe, too. With the strike action now set to go ahead this afternoon, it could disrupt 7% of the global supply of LNG. Here's the full statement from Offshore Alliance's Facebook page: "Despite the Offshore Alliance giving Chevron plenty of opportunity to sort out EBA's across the 3 Chevron facilities, they will finally be facing their day of reckoning. Protected Industrial Action commences at 13:00 today. "Chevron are demanding they be given special concessions in bargaining — a demand which we have put through the shredding machine. "Their bargaining performance has been the most inept effort of any employer the Union has dealt with in the past 5 years and our members have had enough. "When PIA commences, plant on each respective facility will be shut down if there are not competent personnel to undertake handovers during work stoppages. "It's game on, Chevron." Chevron has reportedly made provisions for when workers down tools. Woodside's dispute with its North West Shelf workers was resolved late last month, guaranteeing pay packets of more than $300,000 a year .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Game on': Chevron workers to begin strike at 3pm AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local sharemarket has opened flat on Friday morning, sitting at 7,170 points at 10:20am AEST. (If you want the latest figures, head to the top of the blog.) It's pretty muted across the sectors so far, too. Utilities is up 0.4%, consumer non-cyclicals +0.2%, and healthcare and financials up 0.1% each. Industrials, energy and basic materials are the sectors in the most negative territory, down 0.8% each, while real estate is down 0.3%, and technology and consumer cyclicals have dipped 0.1% each. Meanwhile, news that Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will visit Beijing later this year has seen a positive jump for Treasury Wine Estates. The top movers so far: Treasury Wine Estates +2.9% Paladin Energy +2% Bellevue Gold +1.7% Boral +1.4% Auckland International Airport +1.4% And the bottom movers: Link Administration -3.5% Block -3.1% Mineral Resources -3% Nine Entertainment -2.4% Sayona Mining -2.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens flat as Treasury Wine Estate leads the gains

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

image.altText: A close up of Meghan Markle smiling and waving at the camera, walking through a crowd of people

items.synopsis: The men in their 60s plead guilty over the messages, which also featured references to Britain's first prime minister of colour, Rishi Sunak.

title.children: Former UK police behind 'absolutely appalling' racist messages about Meghan Markle

image.altText: A satellite image showing Australia, New Zealand and an enormous mushroom cloud from a volcanic eruption in the Pacific ocean

items.synopsis: In January 2022, a mega explosion from the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano generated a coast-battering tsunami and vivid sunsets. Now we know the extent of the eruption's devastation below the waves.

title.children: We knew the Tongan volcanic eruption was massive. Now we know what happened on the sea floor

image.altText: Russia's President Vladimir Putin, India's PM Narendra Modi and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

items.synopsis: When the G20 began in 2008 against a backdrop of a global economic crisis, nations came together to fix problems both internationally and at home. Fifteen years later, the event is struggling to even get a full list of attendees.

title.children: Demolished slums, new roads, and animal control: India is going all out for the G20, but is it still an effective forum?

image.altText: A man with a moustache in front of a party tent.

items.synopsis: Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden, accused of killing his stepfather Robert Lumsden last month, will be suspended from his role in local government on full pay until the next election in March 2024.

title.children: Gold Coast councillor charged with stepfather's murder accepts voluntary suspension

image.altText: Man wearing holds gun in desert

items.synopsis: The insurgents attacked a boat carrying dozens of civilians across the flooded plains of two towns.

title.children: Dozens dead in suspected Islamic insurgent boat attack in Mali

image.altText: A comparison of teeth from three koalas species.

items.synopsis: Scientists say teeth from the species have been found at a 25-million-year-old fossil bed south of Alice Springs. It is the first-ever record of koalas living in the Northern Territory.

title.children: New prehistoric koala named for its thorn-like teeth discovered in Northern Territory

image.altText: The Webb Ellis Cup is held up in the air.

items.synopsis: The Wallabies are ranked ninth in the world ahead of the 2023 Rugby World Cup, but coach Eddie Jones still thinks they can win. Here's everything you need to know about the tournament in France.

title.children: Who the Wallabies are up against at the Rugby World Cup 2023
